dockerfiles/heat-container-agent/Dockerf.message: please keep the client. This kind of removals can break things we don't expect. Old deployments that missed a cherry-pick for example.
Oops I was trying to install greenlet from github directly but that seems to bloat the HCA image to 500M up from 200M which is clearly not desirable.

deployment/kernel/kernel-baremetal-ansib.message:
libvirt also uses a range of ephemeral ports for live migration[1] but it is outside of the local port range so shouldn't be necessary to reserve it here

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/commit/7594d871564562c72f2cbadb2f95d8fc248d1c7f/deployment/nova/nova-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml#L402

deployment/kernel/kernel-baremetal-puppe.message: with https://review.openstack.org/561784 the libvirt port range was changed to 61152-61215
with https://review.openstack.org/561784 the libvirt port range was changed to 61152-61215 in tripleo
if we have a per service-based templating approach, I could move the latter for the qpid templates

I can see there is only a role specific ExtraSysctlSettings which we should not overload and leave for users' needs perhaps. Not sure it is currently supported to override sysctl settings per-service?

I don't thing we should hardcode 35357 here. What if Keystone isn't deployed in the cloud?

I would rather setup this config per service in their YAML.

doc/source/index.rst.message: You can mention you added this title in your commit message
You can mention you modified this part in your commit message.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I would argue that overriding deserialization in a subclass is not valid anyway (as evidenced by the few cases in the nova tree, which we know are invalid). The RPC layer deserializes objects with the base class always, not the class from the registry:

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.versionedobjects/blob/master/oslo_versionedobjects/base.py#L898

I'm sure this came up because someone wanted to do something evil in the (de-)serialization routines of a nested object, but there's really no legit use case for overriding it anywhere that I know of. The problem here, of course, is that any object-specific behaviors that you embed into the deserialization routine would be unversioned and not guaranteed to be present and identical on either side of a conversation. Imagine two nodes passing objects between each other, where one has a modified deserialization routine that attempts to fix up something during object construction. That is behavior that should normally be assigned a version, and handled according to the versioning rules, but hidden inside the deserialization path.

If we've got a situation in nova that we've created for ourselves through prior transgressions, then we should handle that there. Baking that into the base layers here just makes it look like we should be able to and/or allow that behavior elsewhere.

I'll be glad to submit a patch decorating that routine with sufficient comments to warn against overriding it.

Isn't it better to just have the subnet UUID?
For consistency purposes we want to map 1 Neutron Subnet to (Subnet Port Group, DHCP Options ) row pair in OVN so having the subnet UUID allows better matching.

To figure out if it belongs or not I think that you may want to fetch all subnet port groups (not sure if db_find can match the name by 'startswith' or something like that, need to check); otherwise what you're doing is fine but perhaps we need as well the subnet id.

Not sure I follow.

Each subnet belonging to a network with DHCP enabled should have a Port Group associated to it (external_id: subnet uuid).

What could change is the IP allocations of ports. For example you can remove the IP allocation of a given port from a particular subnet. What you need to do in this case is remove that port from such subnet Port Group.

I don't think you need the network uuid for anything but for performance reasons you can fetch all the subnet PGs from a particular subnet if you want to *also* add the network uuid to the external_ids. Another option is fetch all the subnets from a network. (new ovsdbapp indexes may help here)

On the other hand from L617, this function calculates the new vs old allocations. You can calculate the subnets at the same time for efficiency.

After this, you'll remove the port from the detached subnets PGs and add the port to the attached subnet PGs.

Does this make sense?
subnet id may have changed and the goal here is to find the 'old' uuids. The old uuids are in the name or something we can store in the external ids as well. Make sense?

I was expecting that we would be doing the load delete in each subcloud as part of the orchestration (which also does the load import for each subcloud). Why would we use dcorch to do the delete?

I was thinking that the load delete could be done centrally at another time (e.g. prior to the import for the next upgrade) and when it does, the delete must be propagated to the subclouds as we don't want the next import to fail as it exceeds the max number of loads allowed. For this reason the delete has to be done via dcorch so it can be retried in case the subcloud is down.

However, deleting the old load in the subcloud as part of the orchestration sounds like a better idea. I will remove this logic.

Yes - I prefer not to have any sysinv imports in dcmanager. We should be accessing sysinv purely through the cgts-client/REST API and I think it is bad practice to import the sysinv package just for the constants (it comes with a lot of other code that would be dangerous to use).

I think it makes sense for the sysinv client (file sysinv_v1.py) and sysinv api proxy in dcorch to reference the constants defined in sysinv. Otherwise the 2 lists of constants can be out of sync as people don't always remember to update dcorch code when they update sysinv code pertaining to these constants. 

It's the same reason for sysinv client in starlingx-dashboard to import constants defined in sysinv instead of defining its own.

Having said that, there are only a few constants referenced in this particular file. I can define them in dcorch constants but in the future if we decide to increase the number of loads allowed or upload 3 instead of 2 files, etc.. we will have to make changes in 2 places. Let me know if this approach is still preferable.
You should be able to use the cleanup() in dcorch/api/proxy/common/utils.py and remove the dependency on sysinv constants POST_FILE_TAGS.

nova/network/neutronv2/api.py.message:
So Sean and I looked at this last week, but apparently forgot to make any notes, so I'll summarize here.

What's changing is that list_ports is now being done as admin. This raises a couple of questions:
- Do we get a different answer (a different set of ports) than when we list_ports as the user? We're filtering by the instance and tenant anyway.
- Was this list_ports-as-user acting as a stealth auth check for the flow, the rest of which is using admin? If this code path has appropriate policy checks from the various places where it can be initiated, this is presumably not an issue.

Thanks for your review.

The reply to your questions are as follows:

1. As we are filtering by the instance's uuid and project id, we will get the same ports as user or admin is doing the list_ports. The user from the context can get all of the ports attached on the instance that he can see.

2. Policy checks have been done in nova-api when nova received a REST call. I think this list_ports-as-user is not a stealth auth check for the flow.
This should have been allowing the long-running operation you were undergoing, without having to be admin.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: Unnecessary to increase the size for worker nodes
What will happen on an upgrade to stx.4.0 if the size is changed here?

The stx4.0 will require an additional 10GB to accommodate large post requests. Depending on the current available scratch space, the system host-fs-modify command may need to be run for both controllers prior to the upgrade. Alternatively, it can be done as part of the upgrade playbook(?). David has been added to the review.

In any case, the required additional disk space and related steps will have to be documented.

I am not familiar with how we handle filesystem size changes over upgrades. Just want you to ensure this is not going to break anything. If a manual action is required by the user we will want to document it in the release notes.

If a load import request, payload size is ~2.1G, is going through the dcorch proxy:

2 x tempfile created by proxy + 2 x tempfile created by sysinv-api + 1 x payload written to disk by sysinv-api to staging area

Total = 5 x 2.1 = ~10G

The files in staging area are cleaned up after the import is complete. The tempfiles are closed before each component returns the response to the caller.
Please explain how the 10GB is calculated. Shouldn't each component involved be freeing its temp space when it is done with it?
Thanks Brent, will make sure scratch size allocation on worker nodes is unchanged.
Interesting question. What if scratch size is > 16G prior to the upgrade? I think we should leave the resize to the upgrade-prep script. Thoughts?
I think it would be better to add a 'group' parameter to platform::filesystem and default it to root. That way the group can be set correclty when the mountpoint is created.
Tried that (see line 14) and it didn't work. Looks like filesystem creation does not have code to change file ownership and permission and exec is required. See the existing exec on line 103.
OK - then please move this exec into that class (at line 105) so it works for anyone using platform::filesystem with a group other than root.
I would prefer to have the same mode/group on controller and worker hosts. Also, if the group is sys_protected, why would we add "other" access?
Can the scratch filesystem on the controller still be resized e.g. via system host-fs-modify controller-0  scratch=20 '?  (sysinv only allows to resize to an increasing size)

Per comment in patchset#4:   
"> Can the scratch filesystem on the controller still be resized e.g. via system host-fs-modify controller-0  scratch=20 '?  ..."
This is the default size at creation. The user should be able to size up this fs at run time if available disk space allows.

doc/source/devref/exceptions.rst.message: Indentation for rest documents can be somehow confusing. Here should be exactly three spaces indent, so that it aligned with the name of the directive (which is "image" in this case).

(Kubernetes, Keystone, Neutron, OVS)

In documentation, I'd expect to have full names, instead of slang short names, so that it would be absolutely clear, what we are referring to.

as I understand "CNIBindingFailure" will have this error type. So does it mean that after some attempts to bind/unbind an interface CNI will fail? Or what kind of "action" expects to be done for this case?

All of those exceptions might be treated differently depending on a case. I might've missed that, but even in this document, there is no explanation, why we do need this.

I guess the blueprint/spec is an overkill here, so that I'd expect, there is a solid use case/purpose of this structured exceptions hierarchy covered.

Could you elaborate on that a little bit please? Example of usage would be beneficial too.

The main idea behind this patch is to avoid restarting controller/CNI pod. There are various cases in the code where an exception is raised, but the same is not caught anywhere. This will lead to a restart of the container. The restarting of container has various side effects like leak of neutron resources. 

Sure for some cases a restart is inevitable but for other cases it could be avoided. For e.g. in mulit_vif.py we raise InvalidKuryrNetworkAnnotation which is not caught anywhere and will lead to the restart of the kuryr controller. But in this case we could have avoided a restart as this is not an error related to controller per say. You can find similar cases in CNI as well.

The idea behind the spec is that we should have a agreed upon way in which the drivers can raise exceptions and same are caught in the handlers and depending on their severity are handled accordingly.

This should be used as both NonFatal and Transient type. For  e.g. in case of a delete request, the tap interface might be already gone as the network namespace of the container is deleted, in this case we should raise the error with type as NonFatal. But let's say a case when ADD commands fails can be a Transient type which will eventually lead to a CNI restart.
